item.title: Megabonk: Best CL4NK Builds
item.description:
Megabonk has 20 different characters for players to try out. Fox and Sir Oofie are the first characters that players will get access to in Megabonk , but as they explore more of the game and complete quests, they'll gain access to plenty more characters. Each character has different base stats and starting weapons as well as unique RNG Blessing abilities and walking styles.

Once players complete the first tier of the Forest map and purchase the revolver, they'll unlock CL4NK as a character. This guide will give players an overview of CL4NK in Megabonk and give them suggestions on weapons and tomes that could help them make it to any final swarm alive.

CL4NK Overview

Before players start thinking of CL4NK builds, they must become familiar with the particularities of this character. Here are CL4NK's base stats:

  • Max HP: 40
  • HP Regen: 10
  • Shield: 50

While CL4NK can be a great character in Megabonk , but his HP and speed are not the best, which makes it harder to get through the early stages of a run with this character.

To take CL4NK to the next level, players will want to take advantage of his unique RNG Blessing, Crit Happens, which increases chances to get a critical hit by 1 percent each time he levels up. It is key that they select weapons and tomes that pair well with the Revolver and the Crit Happens ability.

Best CL4NK Builds in Megabonk

Below, players can take a look at the weapons and tomes that best complement CL4NK's starting weapon and unique stats. Of course, these are not set in stone; players can and should try out these options but also experiment with other weapons and tomes. Additionally, the items that they're able to obtain during a run can change everything, and they might work better with other weapons and tomes.

Best Weapon for CL4NK

  • Pistol
  • Firestaff or Axe or Bananarang or Slutty Rocket
  • Lightning Staff
  • Firewalker or Aura

Pistol, Firestaff, Axe, Bananrang, Slutty Rocket, and Lightning are all great options for CL4NK, as they can benefit from most upgrades that players will inevitable get for this character. Whether they choose to increase quantity and precision or reduce cooldown, these weapons will get better stats. It is key to increase the number of projectiles for these weapons whether it's through weapon upgrades, tomes, items, or charge shrines.

The Pistol, Firestaff, Bananarang, Slutty Rocket, and Axe can hit several enemies at once and the Lightning Staff can deal with hordes. However, they're mostly ranged weapons, and it is important to damage enemies that might get too close. Players can opt for Firewalker, especially if they're already investing on projectile count, as it'll take out enemies on their tail. However, if they'd rather have a safe perimeter all around them, they can choose Aura instead.

Best Tomes for CL4NK

  • Precision Tome
  • Quantity Tome
  • Damage Tome
  • Shield Tome
  • Cooldown Tome

There are two tomes that are almost mandatory when playing as CL4NK in Megabonk : the Precision Tome and the Quantity Tome. These tomes will maximize the damage that CL4NK can do with critical hits. His projectile count will go up with the Quantity Tome, and chances to hit critcs will also increase thanks to the Precision Tome.

Given how frequently players will be hitting critcs with CL4NK, the Demonic Blade would be a great item to obtain, as it has a chance of healing the player when they deal critical damage, but they would have to get lucky in order to get it from a chest, the Shady Guy, or a Moai Shrine. If players don't feel secure playing on such low HP, they can invest in a Shield or HP Tome.

However, if they want to focus exclusively on hitting their opponents as hard as possible, they can pick the Cooldown Tome or the Damage Tome. The former will reduce the cooldown of their weapons, meaning that CL4NK will pull them out much more regularly. The latter increases the damage of each weapon, which means that his critical hits will be a lot more powerful.

9.0 /10

Megabonk

item.title: 10 PlayStation 2 Games That Are Masterpieces
item.description:
The PS2 is one of those consoles where they nailed everything right. It was a successful console that boosted the power of its predecessor with cutting-edge graphics. It still played CDs along with PS1 games via backwards compatibility, and it even served as a cheap DVD player for a long time.

Best of all, the games for it were excellent, as the PS2 had one of the greatest libraries of all time. Most of the best games are so top-notch that they even play great today on native hardware. They may play better with ports, remasters, and remakes, but the sign of a quality game is being able to enjoy it on the original hardware untouched. The range of the console's best games will include a broad list of genres to avoid having one dominate the list.

Final Fantasy 10

A Pilgrimage With No End

Final Fantasy 10
25
9.7 /10
Released
December 17, 2001

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Mild Blood, Mild Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

Final Fantasy 10 is an impeccable turn-based RPG that has been ported numerous times thanks to HD collections. That said, it’s still enjoyable on the PS2, and some even prefer it over ports as it avoids new content like the Dark Aeons.

The turn-based gameplay was innovative as it allowed players to swap out characters in the midst of battle. Summons could be controlled for the first time, and the story was brutally sad, but heartfelt. Best of all, its mini-game, Blitzball, may be the best in the series.

God Of War

For Sparta!

God of War (2005)
8.7 /10
Released
March 22, 2005

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Powered by

God of War was something the PS2 had not seen before: a mature game that did not skip out on the gore or spectacle of action. It also had a repugnant main character, Kratos, who was on an understandable journey of revenge. That said, it still didn’t justify some of his actions.

Love him or hate him, Kratos became a PlayStation icon for years to come, and his character eventually had a redeeming arc in the 2018 reboot. There’s also an HD collection that made it as far as the PS3.

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas

Taking Back The Streets

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas
112
8.6 /10
Released
October 26, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs
Powered by

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was the third and final main game in the series on the PS2, and it was the biggest one yet. Set in a new location, San Andreas, which is somewhere vaguely in California, players could roam the streets or countryside, which was also a new feature. They could level up their character’s skills, like to run faster, and take over territories in gang wars. There was also an HD version, which some fans didn’t like as much as this pure original flavor, which still feels great to play today.

Kingdom Hearts 2

A Slow Start, But A Strong Finish

Kingdom Hearts 2
Action RPG
Hack and Slash
Systems
Released
March 28, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Mild Blood, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Powered by

Kingdom Hearts 2 is technically the third game in the series, but it's the main one that pushed the franchise forward. The original and this sequel are some of the best-looking PS2 action RPGs to this day, which is why they cleaned up so nicely in the various HD ports.

The hero, Sora, gained new powers, like the ability to go into various forms. The game's Disney worlds were fresh, and the addition of Organization 13 gave the series an overarching villain to fight against. The one thing some players had a problem with was the beginning, which was slow, but it helped set the tone.

Marvel Vs. Capcom 2: New Age Of Heroes

Pixel Perfecting Fighting

Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes
Fighting
Systems
Released
June 29, 2000
ESRB
t
Engine
NAOMI

Powered by

Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes started in arcades, but the ports to consoles, like the PS2, are legendary. The game is widely available on modern consoles via various ports and collections, but the physical PS2 copy still sells for a high price.

It’s simply the best fighting game on the PS2 thanks to its roster of villains and heroes from the Marvel and Capcom universes. When it comes to visuals, sprites will always stand the test of time next to polygonal models.

Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater

Jungle-Based Stealth

Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater (2004)
9.6 /10
Released
November 17, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Language, Sexual Themes
Powered by

Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater just got a proper remake, and has received various ports over the years, but the PS2 original is still legendary. No one will ever forget hearing “Snake Eater” blast out after the Virtuous Mission, or the first time they pulled off a great fake-out with camouflage.

There are a lot of mechanics that made it special for a stealth game on PS2, but perhaps its greatest legacy is being known as one of the best prequels of all time. Big Boss certainly had a troubled past.

NBA Street Vol. 2

Three-On-Three Perfection

NBA Street Vol.2
Sports
Systems
Released
April 29, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Powered by

NBA Street Vol. 2 is one of the best sports games on the PS2, and it is still fun to play alone or with friends thanks to a solid foundation of mechanics. It simplified basketball just like NBA Jam did for consoles and arcades in the 90s. Three-on-three basketball in small street courts made it less of a spectacle. It also added a nice root to the sport with a sizzling style, but unfortunately, none of this original trilogy ever made it off the console.

Okami

The Legend Of Wolf

Okami
8.3 /10
Released
September 19, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood and Gore, Crude Humor, Fantasy Violence, Partial Nudity, Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco
Powered by

Okami was made to stand the test of time thanks to its cel-shaded art style mixed with a watercolor aesthetic. It certainly looks better with its HD ports, but there’s no reason the PS2 game is inferior.

Set up like a Zelda adventure, players will explore a blighted fantasy land of Japan as a wolf god who has to reclaim land and make it blossom again. Funny, action-packed, and full of cool puzzle dungeons, some would even call it one of the best Zelda games that Nintendo never made.

Ratchet & Clank: Going Commando

Leveling Up Platformers

Ratchet & Clank: Going Commando
Third-Person Shooter
Platformer
Systems
8.5 /10
Released
November 11, 2003
ESRB
Teen // Mild Violence

Powered by

Ratchet & Clank: Going Commando is the second game in the series, and it took the franchise to new heights. What started as a good platformer with inventive weapons turned into an RPG as Ratchet could now level up his health, and the weapon evolved with EXP. It was that little extra spice that made everything nice, and the series has never gone back.

3D platformers can be hard to keep timeless, but Ratchet & Clank: Going Commando nailed everything the first time. Unfortunately, it only got an HD upgrade as far as the PS3 and PS Vita.

Resident Evil 4

Evil Knows No Bounds

Resident Evil 4
7 /10
24
9.3 /10
Released
January 11, 2005

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Language
Powered by

Resident Evil 4 may have started in 2005 as a GameCube game, but by the end of the year, it was made better via the PS2 port. It reinvented the Resident Evil formula with a new camera angle, a shop system, a different type of virus, and Leon S. Kennedy getting a big makeover. The native Spanish-speaking infected brought an extra edge to the horror, and fans will never be able to sleep again without thinking of their groaned words. It can be enjoyed on most modern hardware between the HD remaster and the remake.

item.title: How to Win at Zeni Hajiki in Ghost of Yotei (Good With Coins)
item.description:
Unlike Ghost of Tsushima , where Jin Sakai didn't have the time for such a lark, Ghost of Yotei features a mini-game known as Zeni Hajiki. While previously teased as something Gwent -like, this coin game is much simpler and more reminiscent of Fable's pub games, where players carefully launch a coin across the table to touch another coin. Zeni Hajiki doesn't include any collecting or strategic elements, so the entire mini-game is available from the start and doesn't evolve throughout Atsu's adventure.

Zeni Hajiki is one of the most reliable ways to quickly earn coins (mon) in Ghost of Yotei , granting around 500 coins per win. However, despite its straightforward rules, some players might find it too difficult and punishing. Even a single mistake often leads to losing, as Atsu's opponents rarely miss, even on medium difficulty. Controlling the precise power of the R2 trigger for coin flicks with no visual cues can also be tricky. Luckily, there's a subtle trick that can make winning this coin game almost trivial.

How to Make Zeni Hajiki Easy in Ghost of Yotei

Just like the case of removing black bars during horse riding that the game doesn't explain for some reason, there's an easy way to make Zeni Hajiki easier and almost guarantee a win, if players are careful. All that's needed is to go to the Accessibility Options, find “Zeni Hajiki Shot Power Display,” and turn it on . This will show the predicted shot distance on the Zeni Hajiki table, allowing players to always know how far the coin will travel.

After turning the power display on, all players need to do is make sure the predicted circle just barely touches the targeted coin (as shown in the image below), then carefully release the R2 trigger. This option makes Zeni Hajiki consistently easy to play, almost trivializing the process . Players who treat this mini-game mainly as a way to earn extra coins in Ghost of Yotei may want to stick with this method for the rest of the game.

There's currently a bug in Ghost of Yotei that sometimes causes coins to glitch, fall through the table, or disappear while playing Zeni Hajiki. Unfortunately, if this happens and players haven't manually saved beforehand, reloading the checkpoint will result in losing their bet. Hopefully, the issue will be addressed in upcoming patches.

Alternatively, players can use save scumming when trying to win Zeni Hajiki without using the accessibility option that makes the mini-game too easy, or to avoid losing money due to the bug. To do this, open the game menu, go to the save options, manually save in a free slot, and only then begin a Zeni Hajiki round. If things go sideways, exit to the start menu and load the manual save instead of pressing “Continue” to retry without losing any hard-earned coins.

How to Get the Good With Coins Trophy in Ghost of Yotei

Winning at Zeni Hajiki is important even for players who aren't focused on earning extra coins in Ghost of Yotei and prefer making money through bounties. Each gambling den offers a unique charm for Atsu after winning two Zeni Hajiki matches, so even those who don't enjoy the mini-game shouldn't ignore it, as they might miss out on valuable rewards that enhance combat, stealth, defense, or utility.

By winning any charm in one of the game's gambling dens for the first time, players will also unlock the “Good with Coins” trophy (Bronze) . Note that there's only one unique charm available in each of Ghost of Yotei's gambling dens, so after claiming it, players can continue playing there just for fun or to earn additional coins.

9.8 /10
10 /10

Ghost of Yotei

item.title: CloverPit: Best Lucky Charms
item.description:
Panik Arcade’s CloverPit is a roguelite horror game that’s a blend of slot machine mechanics with a claustrophobic, unsettling atmosphere. To pay off their debt, players need to try their luck at the demonic-looking Slot Machine. Interestingly, players can manipulate the slot machine and increase payouts by using Lucky Charms. These Charms can give you more control over symbol appearance and value, and overall Luck in CloverPit . Since you can only purchase a few Lucky Charms at a time, it’s important to choose the best ones that can turn a modest win into a massive jackpot. To make it easy for players, we’ve put together this CloverPit Lucky Charm Tier List.

S Tier Lucky Charms

Charm Name

Cost

Perks

Cat Food

4 Tickets

  • Gives you +2 extra Spins in each round.
  • Prevents bad spin chains.
  • Scales into huge benefits in the late game.

Horseshoe

3 Tickets

  • Doubles the effect of your "random trigger" Charms.
  • Creates powerful synergies with Fake Coin and Peppers.

Lucky Cat

1 Ticket

  • Perfect for interest builds.
  • Easily triggered to help hit multiple patterns, which can boost your coin supply between deadlines.

Fake Coin

2 Tickets

  • Gives you +1 extra Spin when triggered with an immediate +4 Luck bonus.
  • Perfect for high-Luck, Jackpot-synergy builds in late runs.

Stain

1 Ticket

  • Boosts the value of all patterns whenever four or more symbols trigger.
  • Huge scaling in the mid-to-late game.

Shroom

2 Tickets

  • Doubles all symbol values in the middle of the round.
  • Leads to immense payoffs in the late games.
  • Synergizes well with Charms that grant extra spins.

Car Battery

1 Ticket

  • Doesn't take up a Charm slot.
  • Instantly restores Energy to your button Charms.
  • Triggers red-button loops in late-game.

Clover Voucher

2 Tickets

  • Gives a free, instant bonus of 4 tickets.
  • Doesn’t take up a Charm slot.
  • Gives an immediate, powerful spike in your economy early in your run.

Cloverpot

2 Tickets

  • Great early pickup that gives you extra tickets every deadline.
  • This passive income can help you purchase new Charms and sustain long, deep runs.

A Tier Lucky Charms

Charm Name

Cost

Perks

Raging Capitalist

4 Tickets

  • Features a scaling trigger chance that makes it incredibly powerful in later runs.
  • Less impactful early on, but has a strong long-term payoff.

Megaphone

7 Tickets

  • Doubles the effect of your red telephone abilities.
  • Comes with a very expensive cost, but is game-changing for high-synergy builds.

Hamsa

3 Tickets

  • Gives a +7 Luck bonus on your final spin of the round.
  • Perfect for Luck builds.
  • Its effect can be inconsistent when you have early deadlines.

Stonks

2 Tickets

  • Gives a permanent passive boost by adding +5% interest.
  • Although it has a low short-term effect, it can definitely scale your economy in longer runs.

Toy Train

2 Tickets

  • Adds +5 Luck after you get two dead spins in a row.
  • Even though it only triggers in situations where you’re losing, it is an inexpensive safety net to help pull you out of a cold streak.

Number 1

3 Tickets

  • Enhances the appearance of extra yellow patterns.
  • It also restores Energy to active Charms, but it only reaches its full potential in a yellow-heavy build.

Number 2

3 Tickets

  • Promotes extra non-yellow patterns and restores Energy to active Charms.
  • Highly effective in builds focused on mixed patterns, though it requires a Button Charm synergy to reach full potential.

Red Shiny Rock

1 Ticket

  • Adds +4 Luck after a Red Button press.
  • Restores Energy to a button Charm.
  • Requires a specific button synergy to be effective.

Cloverpet

2 Tickets

  • Adds a +1 multiplier for every 5 tickets you currently hold.
  • Not that effective if your ticket count is low, but is great for long-term economy scaling.

Red Pepper

1 Ticket

  • Adds +5 Luck bonus upon a random trigger.
  • Its usage is limited to only 12 activations per run.

Green Pepper

2 Tickets

  • Gives a very strong +7 Luck boost upon a random trigger, making it excellent for Luck-focused builds.
  • It’s limited to only 9 uses.

Grandma’s Purse

3 Tickets

  • Adds +15% bonus interest to your banked coins, perfect for interest economy builds.
  • However, this powerful boost decays over time, which means you have to use it early in the run.

B Tier Lucky Charms

Charm Name

Cost

Perks

Lemon Picture

2 Tickets

  • Guarantees +2 Lemon symbol spawns per spin.
  • Highly dependent on securing Charms that synergize with Lemon symbols.

Cherry Picture

4 Tickets

  • Guarantees +2 Cherry symbol spawns per spin.
  • Good for runs focused on the Golden Cherry Charm, but needs more cherry synergies to reach its full potential.

Clover Picture

4 Tickets

  • Guarantees +2 Clover symbol spawns per spin.
  • Requires Charms with specific clover synergy to be truly effective.

Bell Picture

3 Tickets

  • Guarantees +2 Bell symbol spawns per spin.
  • Has good synergy potential for highly profitable builds in the late game.
  • Requires Bell-boosting Charms to be most effective.

Golden Seven

3 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Seven spawns.
  • It’s extremely inconsistent and highly dependent on pure luck.

Golden Diamonds

3 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Diamond spawns.
  • Although it offers huge payouts, the Charm is super inconsistent.

Golden Clover

3 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Clover spawns.
  • Highly dependent on other Charms that synergize with Clover symbols.

Golden Coins

3 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Coin spawns and is excellent for boosting your economy.
  • However, its benefit is weak outside dedicated economy builds.

Golden Lemon

2 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Lemon spawns.
  • Only good in dedicated Lemon-focused builds.

Golden Cherry

2 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Cherry spawns.
  • Its full benefit is limited to synergies involving the Golden Cherry symbol itself.

Golden Bell

2 Tickets

  • Gives a +20% chance for Golden Bell spawns.
  • Requires Bell-boosting Charms to be most effective.

Nuclear Button

3 Tickets

  • Triggers the effect of your Button Charms twice upon activation.
  • Reduces one of your available Charm slots.

Lost Briefcase

2 Tickets

  • Gives an instant 30% relief to your current debt.
  • An excellent "Quick save" option for immediately closing a deadline, but can only be used once.

Tarot Deck

1 Ticket

  • Features a multiplier scaling as random triggers occur during a spin.
  • However, this scaling is fragile, as the multiplier resets to 0 easily when certain conditions are met.

C Tier Lucky Charms

Charm Name

Cost

Perks

Coins Picture

3 Tickets

  • Gives a small boost to Coin symbol spawns.
  • Considered weak on its own and requires heavy coin synergy from other Charms to be worth a slot.

Seven Picture

3 Tickets

  • Guarantees extra Seven symbols to spawn on the reel.
  • Its effect is highly reliant on RNG and remains inconsistent, making it a risky choice for most builds.

Diamond Picture

3 Tickets

  • Guarantees +2 Diamond symbol spawns per spin.
  • Takes up a Charm slot and is highly dependent on finding strong diamond synergies.

Holy Bible

1 Ticket

  • Cheap Charm that will cancel a 666 pattern trigger.

CloverPit

item.title: Rumor: Bloober Team Hints at 2 More Versions of Silent Hill 2 Remake
item.description:
The Silent Hill 2 remake website was found to include potential hints of two more versions of the game being in the works. This development arrives mere days before the Silent Hill 2 remake's console exclusivity is scheduled to end.

October 8 will mark the first anniversary of Bloober Team's Silent Hill 2 reimagining releasing to critical acclaim. Ever since its late 2022 reveal, the game was known to be a timed PlayStation 5 console exclusive.

Silent Hill 2 Remake Website May Hint at New Game Versions

With the Silent Hill 2 remake's PS5 exclusivity coming to an end on October 8, the game's website was now found to incorporate possible hints of additional ports being on the horizon. As spotted by Reddit user PracticalSubstance99, the "Buy Now" section of the developer's landing page for the game still lists only Steam and the PlayStation Store under platforms, but its layout incorporates four columns in total. The two extra columns aren't immediately visible in the browser because they don't contain any text right now, being populated by one non-breaking space—" "—each. They may be placeholders for the long-rumored Xbox Series X/S and Switch 2 versions of the Silent Hill 2 remake.

Game Rant was able to independently verify the newly spotted layout quirks. Anyone can do so by bringing up developer tools with the SH2 site open in any modern browser and using the inspect element feature. According to cached site data reviewed by Game Rant, the four-column layout is not a new addition to the landing page. The very first version of the website, which went live immediately following the late 2022 announcement of the Silent Hill 2 remake and its timed PS5 console exclusivity, had already included the two extra columns, but they were undiscovered until now.

Silent Hill 2 Remake May Be the Series' Final Timed Console Exclusive in a While

Although Konami has yet to confirm the game for any console beyond the PS5, the Japanese publisher previously emphasized that its timed exclusivity deal with Sony lasts only 12 months. The move signaled plans to expand the game’s availability later. In recent years, Konami has shown signs of moving away from exclusivity agreements, most recently exemplified by Silent Hill f launching simultaneously across multiple platforms in late September 2025. The Silent Hill 2 remake could hence end up being the series' final timed console exclusive in a while. Its additional ports could be announced as early as October 8, 2025, when its PS5 console exclusivity is scheduled to end.

Two other franchise entries are currently known to be in development: Screen Burn's Silent Hill: Townfall and Bloober Team's Silent Hill 1 remake. No specific platforms have yet been confirmed for either project. Townfall is expected to be the first to hit the market—possibly as early as late 2026, seeing how it's been in the works since at least 2021—but it doesn't yet have a firm release date or window.

72
9.1 /10
9 /10

Silent Hill 2
